content: Intelligence officials and Congress are discussing reducing intelligence spending while maintaining core capabilities. DNI James R. Clapper Jr. warned that sequestration could lead to a 7% cut, or $4 billion, in the National Intelligence Program budget, impacting global coverage and intelligence collection. He highlighted the negative effects of past budget cuts in the 1990s, which distorted the intelligence workforce. Congress passed the FY2013 intelligence authorization legislation in December 2012, signed into law in January 2013. The Intelligence Reform Act of 2004 created a Director of National Intelligence to oversee the intelligence community and advise the President. This was in response to the increased intelligence threats following the 9/11 attacks. The final bill for FY2013 was signed into law in January 2013, reflecting funding above the President's request but below the previous year's appropriation. The Intelligence Reform Act of 2004 established the Director of National Intelligence to improve coordination in the intelligence community following the 9/11 attacks. The act addressed the findings of the 9/11 Commission regarding inadequate coordination and the need for a more agile information gathering network. Congress debated the recommendations of the commission, particularly focusing on the authorities of the DNI in managing and budgeting for technical collection systems. Ultimately, many of the commission's recommendations were adopted with a compromise provision to respect existing statutory authorities. The intelligence community, as defined by 50 U.S.C. 401a(4), includes various agencies such as the CIA, NSA, NGA, and FBI, among others. For more details on intelligence community reform and oversight issues, refer to Appendix A of the report. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis, Department of Homeland Security, along with other intelligence offices/agencies in Cabinet departments, support intelligence community activities. The CIA remains central to analytic efforts globally, producing studies for national security policymakers and conducting covert actions as directed by the President. The Department of Defense houses three major intelligence agencies - NSA, NRO, and NGA. The National Security Agency (NSA), National Reconnaissance Office (NRO), and National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) are key players in the national intelligence budget. NSA focuses on signals intelligence globally, NRO operates reconnaissance satellites, and NGA provides geospatial data for military precision targeting. The Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) handles defense attachés and analytical products for the Department of Defense.
